title: Cat. 111.1 Three People, a Mask, a Fox and a Bird, 1899
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Three People, a Mask, a Fox and a Bird, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile)  
1899  
Only state  
Wood-block print in black ink on thin ivory laid Japanese paper; 100 × 186 mm (image); 127 × 228 mm (sheet)  
Signed recto, lower left, in brush and black ink: PG.  
Inscribed recto, lower right, in brush and black ink: No. 10  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Edward McCormick Blair, 2002.243  
Guérin 75, Kornfeld 58 B  
For the verso, see fig. 111.1.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin carved interchangeable vignettes and headpieces to accompany the text of his self-published journal, Le sourire. For this vignette he used the back of the same block on which he carved Mahana atua four years earlier (cat. 80). On the same side, he also carved a second vignette, Fox, Busts of Two Women, and a Rabbit (cat. 120). The block was carved so that the vignettes face each other; they abut along their bottom edges. The commercially available block was manufactured with a series of four screws to hold smaller segments of boxwood together. The voids left by the apertures from this assemblage were appropriated by the artist to add his initials and to inscribe numbers onto his prints. The block is extant, in the collection of the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C. (fig. 111.1.2).

This impression is printed in black ink. The inking is richer in this impression than it is in a second impression in the museum’s collection (cat. 111.2). The two impressions in the Art Institute collection do not include the signature noted in the catalogue raisonné of Gauguin’s prints. Although the signature was absent from the block when this impression was printed, the artist added it later on. By the time Gauguin used the headpiece in his November 1899 issue of Le sourire (cat. 110), the signature is present.

The block was printed on a thin sheet of mitsumata (est.) paper that was irregularly trimmed along the bottom. In order to successfully print such a thin sheet, a more substantial secondary paper was likely used as a carrier to help facilitate lifting the mitsumata paper from the inked block.

100 × 186 mm (image); 127 × 228 mm (sheet)

Prior to entering the museum’s collection in 2002 the print was mounted with thin threads adhered at each corner, which pulled and created undulations in the thin, fragile sheet. Additionally, there was a line of discoloration around the image from contact with an acidic mat. In 2002, a strip of Japanese paper (40 × 228 mm) sympathetic in appearance and weight to the original was added to protect the bottom edge of the print, and the threads were removed.

The print is in excellent condition.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Nicolai Christian Mustad (1878–1970), Oslo.

Sold by Wildenstein and Company, New York, to Edward McCormick Blair (1915–2010), Chicago, 1972.

Given by Edward McCormick Blair to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Bar Harbor, Maine, Ethel H. Blum Gallery, College of the Atlantic, From Paradise to Eden: Gauguin in Tahiti, Aug. 7–Sept. 12, 1999, cat. 16.

Art Institute of Chicago, Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific; The Edward McCormick Blair Collection, Sept. 6, 2003–Jan. 11, 2004, cat. 32.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 222, cat. 58.

Douglas Druick and Peter Zegers, From Paradise to Eden: Gauguin in Tahiti, exh. cat. (College of the Atlantic, Ethel H. Blum Gallery, 1999), p. 9, cat. 16.

Art Institute of Chicago, Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific; The Edward McCormick Blair Collection, exhibition brochure (Art Institute of Chicago, 2003), cat. 32.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Inscribed lower left, in brush and black ink: PG.

Inscribed lower right, in brush and black ink: No. 10

Inscribed in wood block, upper left, printed in white-line manner: Le Sourire

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">See Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 222, cat. 58.

Fiber analysis was conducted on Tahitian Carrying Bananas (), and mitsumata fiber was confirmed. IPS Testing, Appleton, Wisc., report no. IPS 00592-15, conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. Although Tahitian Carrying Bananas was the only print that was sampled and analyzed, visual examination of the Suite of Late Wood-Block Prints (cats. 91–105) and various prints for Le sourire revealed that these works were also printed on the same type of paper. The appearance, tone, surface quality, weight, and even fiber distribution found in these papers are identical.

Kristi Dahm, condition report, treatment record, and photographic documentation, Nov. 2002, conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 222, no. 58.

Inventory from Alice Adam Ltd., curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 111.1 Three People, a Mask, a Fox and a Bird, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile), 1899.

fig. 111.1.2 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Left, Two Title Pages for “Le sourire,” verso, in or after 1895. Right, Mahana atua, recto, 1894/95. Woodcut block; 20 × 28 cm (7 7/8 × 11 in.). National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., Rosenwald Collection, 1943.3.1726.b, a.

fig. 111.1.1 Verso of Gauguin's Three People, a Mask, a Fox and a Bird, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile) (1899). The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.243.

</section>
